fields.description:
You may get a foreignkey constraint when a chain is executed

This applies to databases which were created when chain results were not stored in the BRS table but its own table.  The chain_stage_result table has a constraint with the chain_result table.  But we no longer put things in the chain_result table so the constraint is not met and saving of the results fails.
fields.summary: Foreign key constraint when running a chain on an old database
telemetry screen should show if plan is in queue or is executing

fields.summary: Activity Stream atom feed throws NPE

fields.description:
I opened a support ticket requesting expanded remote agent platform support and was requested to file a feature enhancement here.

Support Request:

I require the ability to run remote agents on the following platforms which are supported by the Java Service Wrapper.  Please add platform support for the following remote agent environments.
 - AIX
 - HPUX (PA-RISC & IA64)
fields.summary: Add support for additional remote agent platforms

fields.description: This is a 20% project that Cheryl Jerozal and myself worked on. Patch and more information are available here: https://extranet.atlassian.com/display/~cjerozal/Project+-+Bamboo+Build+Comparison+Improvements

fields.description: When setting up Bamboo locally, I ran into several issues (with messages/stacktraces that didn't help much) related to the fact that I did not have JAVA_HOME or M2_HOME environment variables set. Since JAVA_HOME is required for the JDKs to run (I think), and M2_HOME is required for the Maven Builder to function, perhaps Bamboo can detect if the environment variables do not exist, in which case a helpful error message would appear.
fields.summary: Detect missing environment variables

fields.description:
When I try to import a Maven POM from my CVS repository I get the error "Cannot connect to CVS root: Wrong Password."

(see attachment)

However the password specified is exactly the same than the one I specify in another plan to retrieve files from my CVS, and in this case it can connect succesfully to the CVS server.

fields.description:
The current *Create Something* link needs some wording improvements and could do with some functionality/structural revision too.

Firstly, you could change *Create Something* to one of the following:
* *Create or Edit a Project*
or if that's too long,
* *Create or Edit Project*
or if that's too long,
* *Create/Edit Project*

Then, you could change the existing wording at the top of this page (which currently only relates to 'plans') to the following (assuming we're going to call chains 'pipelines' instead):

----

h3. Create or Edit a Project

A Bamboo project consists of logically related 'plans' and 'pipelines'. On this page, you can create or edit a project and add a plan or pipeline to it. Revisit this page if you need to add another plan or pipeline to any accessible project on your Bamboo server.

A plan defines everything that Bamboo requires in order to execute a build. In a plan, you define the source code repository whose content is built, how the build is triggered and which builder to use. _After adding a plan, you can fine tune it by defining its requirements, what artifacts are generated from the build, who will be notified of build results, additional actions performed after the build completes and who has permission to view or perform actions on the plan._

A pipeline allows you to organise one or more plans into 'stages' in which all plans in a stage must build successfully and pass before plans in the next stage can commence building.

----

{quote}Why the _italics_ above??? --- For those who are slightly word-averse, I'd suggest the italicised section above could be optional (i.e. not literally meant to be italicised). In fact, it could be surplus to requirements and removed altogether. However, if you'd like to include the essence of this sentence in a shorter version, I could suggest:
* After adding a plan, you can further fine tune its behaviour.
{quote}

Here are my other suggestions:

I think *Create New Something* section heading should be changed to *Add New Plan or Pipeline* and incorporate _all_ of the following fields:
* *Plan Type* (which should be changed to *Plan or Pipeline*)
* _When Plan is selected:_
** *Build Plan Name*
** *Build Plan Key*
** *Build Description* (which should be changed to *Build Plan Description*)
* _When Pipeline is selected:_
** *Pipeline Name*
** *Pipeline Key*
** *Pipeline Description*

Once you've made this change, you could then change the *Plan Details* section heading (which inherently excludes pipelines) to *Project Details*, which would still retain the fields:
* *Project*
* *Project Name*
* *Project Key*

The *Add New Plan or Pipeline* should then appear under the *Project Details* section.
fields.summary: Suggested wording improvements for the Bamboo "Create Something" page.

fields.summary: BuildManager.deleteBuild method does not provide any argument of type Plan
Using discriminator in ResultSummaryManager
REST API should allow anonymous access to resources available anonymously

fields.description:
I attempted to create a chain/pipeline on Tardigrade (using my test project "GG-Test-Project") and got the following error:
 Project: Plan:
An unexpected error has occurred
Could not find the "GGTESTPROJ-CHAIN2" build

Nevertheless, the pipeline appears to be created. However, when I visit the pipeline's Bamboo page and click the *Activity* tab, I also get this error.

(Sorry - I'm not sure which milestone is Tardigrade is currently running so I couldn't choose the correct *Affects Version/s* item for this issue.)
fields.summary: "An unexpected error has occurred" problem when creating a Chain/Pipeline.

fields.description:
Bamboo is currently on 2.2-alpha-2, it would be great if you could upgrade it to the latest (currently 3.something).

Also, (and bear in mind I haven't looked at the code), bamboo might be referencing streams code, either in templates, js or java. Really it should be providing a plugin point and letting streams inject itself
fields.summary: Upgrade Streams plugin

fields.description:
I've got a bamboo gadget which attempts to ajax load a bamboo artifact. 
If the artifact is readable by anonymous users it works fine. If the artifact is restricted then I get the regular oauth dialogue, follow it to get an oauth token then the next time it loads I get the same dialogue.

Looking at what happens with the request in firebug it appears that it's getting an authorized oauth token, then attempts to retrieve the url using the oauth token and gets a 403 from bamboo.

I'll attach a jar containing the plugin.
fields.summary: Oauth doesn't appear to work when ajax loading the content of an artifact.

fields.description: I can have multiple builds in my queue (looking at it via the live activity screen) and builds that were added to the queue first are not being picked up by agents first, they seem to get chosen randomly.
fields.summary: Builds seem to get picked off the queue in random order

fields.description:
1. Enter all required admin user data, but add an invalid email address (e.g. name without @)
2. submit -> system flags an invalid email address
3. fill in email address and submit again
Result: Dialog reappears with all values lost, requesting values for all fields
fields.summary: Create admin user step loses data after second submit
Export will not renable change detection if export fails

The following error is logged while exporting:
{code}
java.lang.NullPointerException
  at com.atlassian.bamboo.migration.stream.UserMapper.shouldExportUser(UserMapper.java:137)
  at com.atlassian.bamboo.migration.stream.UserMapper.exportData(UserMapper.java:170)
  at com.atlassian.bamboo.migration.XmlMigrator.exportXml(XmlMigrator.java:354)
  at com.atlassian.bamboo.migration.XmlMigrator$$FastClassByCGLIB$$b6578fc7.invoke(<generated>)
  at net.sf.cglib.proxy.MethodProxy.invoke(MethodProxy.java:149)
  at org.springframework.aop.framework.Cglib2AopProxy$CglibMethodInvocation.invokeJoinpoint(Cglib2AopProxy.java:694)

h3. Workaround
Apply the [atlassian-bamboo-migration-2.6.2-SNAPSHOT.jar|http://jira.atlassian.com/secure/attachment/39489/atlassian-bamboo-migration-2.6.2-SNAPSHOT.jar] patch attached to this ticket. To do this:
# Shutdown Bamboo.
# Replace your ../WEB-INF/lib/atlassian-bamboo-migration-2.6.x.jar with [this file|http://jira.atlassian.com/secure/attachment/39489/atlassian-bamboo-migration-2.6.2-SNAPSHOT.jar]
# Restart Bamboo.
fields.summary: LDAP may return null users, leading to NullPointerException during export

fields.description: If the user selects the clone build checkbox we want to hide/disable all the other fields below it (except for the enable checkbox).  We can't use the existing show/hide javascript because the checkbox may not always be on the page (e.g. if there are no existing plans on the server).  See createBuild.ftl for the current freemarker
fields.summary: Javascript to properly handle ui for cloning a build on create plan page

fields.description: Happened on Tardigrade: build shown in the log page as queued, but not in the queue. Build has been stopped manually from UI.
fields.summary: Stopped build stays on the plan log page

fields.description:
Problem and how to reproduce:

After typing my user name and password in login form i press login button.
Then system redirects me to this url:

https://mydomain.tld/bamboo/%2Fstart.action

Result: 

- Page not Found
- The requested URL /bamboo//start.action was not found on this server.

Expected result:
  - Bamboo home page
  - Successfull login.

Fix: After removing %2F from url, then i'm redirected to bamboo home page.
fields.summary: Not Found error after pressing login buton

fields.description: all build summary and build result related pages should be switched from Build to Buildable.
fields.summary: all build summary and build result related pages should be switched from Build to Buildable.

fields.description:
This is mostly an exercise of changing BuildManager references to PlanManager references and ensuring that the appropriate Plan object is loaded.

Listeners should _not_ crash when they are passed a key that is invalid (eg, a subplan key being used to lookup a Plan as TopLevelPlan).
fields.summary: Review all event listeners and make sure they do not throw exceptions when subplan keys are used to lookup builds.

fields.description: A bad agent can quickly consume and fail a large number of builds. Perhaps there can be some detection and consequently a notification and/or disabling of an agent when such a situation arises. An idea [~pleschev] suggested was something similar to fail2ban, where x number of failures in y minutes would trigger the condition.
fields.summary: Bad agents should be detected to prevent them from consuming and consequently failing numerous builds
Subplan should not execute an initial build

fields.description: based on my shipit project
fields.summary: introduce audit log functionality for plan and global configurations

fields.description: In Bamboo 3.0-m1, clicking the star icon on favourite plans does not toggle them anymore. I can click a non-favourite plan to add it to my favourites, but not the other way around --- the page refreshes but nothing changes. I've reproduced this on BDAC and BEAC, from both the dashboard and a plan summary page.
fields.summary: Can't remove favourites by clicking the star icon

fields.description:
Users should be able to upload the keys required for EBS through the web interface.  This is a major pain for JIRA Studio customers and support, as customers are left confused because they don't have access to their server to upload the keys, and so they have to create a support request, and then the support team have to handle that.  For the amount of effort it would take to provide the option to upload the keys, this would be a massive win for JIRA Studio support.

See also https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/JST-2200.
fields.summary: Allow upload of key and certificate for EBS

fields.description: We are having builds trigger on agents with other builds already in progress.  The build will inevitably fail to clean out the build directory, as it contains files in use by the other build.  All our builds are set to force clean, and use the same directory.  This is a huge and terrible bug.
fields.summary: Plans are triggering on agents with other builds in progress

fields.description:
Repositories doing change detection no longer require there to be an initial build.  On first poll they will update their last revision key for that plan, so the next time they poll they have a benchmark to start with.

On this 'first' poll the repository should log this information to the plan log.

e.g. this is currently spat out to bamboo's logs:
[SvnRepository] Never checked logs for 'POLL-DEF' on path 'https://svn.atlassian.com/svn/private/atlassian/bambootest/trunk/successBuild'  setting latest revision to 119055

Obviously we need something a bit more user friendly though...
fields.summary: Repositories should log to plan log when they don't have an initial vcs version

fields.description:
If you're running your tests against a web application running in Cargo, there is an application server log produced as part of the build. Because they include messages and exceptions directly from the application, application server logs can actually be much more helpful in debugging build failures than the build logs and test output which Bamboo automatically captures.

At the moment, we configure these log files as build artifacts so they get stored with the build. However, I'd like to see application server logs become "first-class citizens" in Bamboo. For me, that would mean: 

* Application server logs should be part of the "Logs" tab in Bamboo, in addition to the current build and plan logs.
* Application server logs should be available while the build is running, so you can see what is happening on the app server during the tests.

At the moment, interacting with the application server logs as artifacts is workable but clunky. The above two features would improve things dramatically.

The application server log location would be optional and configurable on a per-plan basis. When running with Cargo, the default location is 'target/output.log' in the webapp module of the project, so this should probably be the default value.

Potentially you could combine this feature request into a generic "track arbitrary log files during builds" request, because Java app server logs are just our particular instance of this general problem.
fields.summary: Make application server logs first-class citizens - available on build summaries, tracked during builds

fields.description:
When configuring the PhpUnit Builder,
under the option:
"Log test execution to XML file
Relative path to file where PHPUnit will store log test execution in XML format (option --log-xml)."

fails in PhpUnit 3.4.3+ since --log-xml is now deprecated option in PhpUnit.
Message: The --log-xml option is deprecated, please use --log-junit instead

Therefore the only way to successfully build with PhpUnit 3.4.3+ is to have "Log test execution to XML file" disabled.
fields.summary: phpunit --log-xml option deprecated in phpunit 3.4.3+

fields.description:
The following critical errors have been found:

* failed tests are not listed neither in web UI, nor in REST API. The fact that tests have failed are apparently known to bamboo, because the whole build fails, but there is no indication of the reason for failure other than the build log. 
* when using MSTest as a testing framework, the {{className}} attribute of the test reported in REST is equal to the unqualified test method name. I think the same thing is happening in web UI - class name is not shown
* when using NUnit as a testing framework, method name reported in REST is fully qualified method name (assembly/class/method), which is different than what is shown for MSTest - where just an unqualified method name is reported
fields.summary: Builder for MSBuild is not handling tests correctly

fields.summary: Remote agent will not startup

fields.description:
I have multiple component builds set up in bamboo, with the actual dependencies indicated in the build dependencies for those builds.   Set with a blocking strategy of "Block build if parent plans have unbuilt changes" - but I don't think this affects the issue.

Because of the graph of dependencies, and the current methodology of triggering builds in bamboo, the components at the end of the dependency tree can get build multiple times for the same root reason/submission.

Consider the builds:
|| Build || Parent Plans ||
| parent | |
| child-A | parent |
| grandchild-B | parent \\
child-A |

If a change is submitted to parent source, then on a successful build, both child-A and grandchild-B builds are queued. Once child-A successfully builds, grandchild-B is queued.

Grandchild-b gets built twice (with non-deterministic results on the first build since it uses the current parent results and the previous child-A results).
fields.summary: "Block build if parent plans have unbuilt changes" doesn't block when parent builds are queued

fields.description:
In the current Bamboo documentation we have a page regarding customizing Elastic AMI images:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Creating+a+Custom+Elastic+Image

At the top of this document there is a large heading that says "Please note that we do not support custom elastic images. Consider customising the elastic agents started from your existing image instead."  However, at the very bottom of the page there is also a line under *Need Help?* that reads:

* if you are having problems with any of the Bamboo-related steps of this process, please raise a ticket in the Bamboo project on our support system and our support team will respond as soon as possible.

As this process is unsupported I think we should remove the link as it's could be causing confusion for customers as what's supported.  For example we had a customer file a ticket related to this today:

https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JST-7309
fields.summary: Documentation for Support on AMI Customization is Contradictory

fields.description:
Currently if remote client executes a build (or rather adds it to the queue) has no way to identify this build later on.
It makes some integrations of 3rd party tools (in fact also JIRA via custom plugins) with Bamboo quite difficult.
fields.summary: Build identifier should be returned to caller using remote API execute build (/api/rest/executeBuild.action)

fields.description: If an agent goes offline the build should fail. Or make it configurable if the build should fail in this case.
fields.summary: Fail the build if an agent goes offline

fields.description:
A build summary lists commits to source control. Please see below for an example. ETOOLS-4287 is a JIRA id. Does Bamboo already have the ability to generate a URL to the JIRA incident like Fisheye does?

Changes
This build was manually triggered by Terris Linenbach. 

 
Terris Linenbach 
[ETOOLS-4287] Add VERBOSE option to check_source.pl
fields.summary: URL to JIRA from the "Changes" screen

fields.description:
We recently added a second agent to several of our build servers and had to manually copy/paste the agent capabilities when setting up those new agents.  Given that the agents are on the same server (and therefore will have virtually identical capabilities) it would have been ideal to have a way to bulk copy all capabilities of agent 1 in order to seed the capabilities of agent 2.

I found myself looking at the capabilities page for "Server 1 Agent 2" and hoping to find the "Clone all capabilities from Server 1 Agent 1" button.
fields.summary: Cloning agent capabilities when adding multiple agents on a single server.

fields.description:
If there is _one_ plan in the queue that qualifies for an elastic instance to be started more than one instance will be started. 
The reason could be that it takes up to 4 min to start an elastic agent. The el instance manager checks every minute if there is a qualifying plan in the queue and start another instance (unnecessarily)

fields.description:
If Bamboo encounters null characters '0x00' it writes to buidresult XML file or the database.

Postgresql can't store null characters in the database so Bamboo throws an error while storing build results in the database.

We should filter out null characters from build output.
fields.summary: Strip null characters while processing build results

fields.description:
If using an integer value in an action and webwork converts the value from the UI to the integer for you, if that conversion fails it returns a generic error message.  This message is not pretty.  

It would be nice if we could figure out how to make the message nicer. Or remove the default message altogether maybe?
fields.summary: Fix the default webwork "Invalid Number" message.

fields.description:
The SharePoint Connector builds are consistently failing due to what appears to be a problem with the Bamboo remote agent.

The problem started occurring sometime in the last few weeks, since I last ran a build.

Here are the builds that have failed with this problem:

    * [https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/CSI-DEF-248]
    * [https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/CSI-DEF-249]

When CSI-DEF-248 failed, I noticed that the bamboo remote agent installed on the SharePoint build server was only "atlassian-bamboo-agent-installer-2.3.jar". So, before running CSI-DEF-249, I upgraded the remote agent to "atlassian-bamboo-agent-installer-2.6.jar". However, CSI-DEF-249 still failed with the same error.

Looking at the build logs, the build actually completes successfully (with some test errors), but the build is marked as failed with an exception when Bamboo tries to package up the error failures.

Here's the error from build summary screen (this exception does not appear in the build log)

fields.description:
For a large number of build plans, the dependency management screen for editing plans is practically unusable.  It takes a long time to load and finding a particular plan in the list is ridiculous.  I propose an "autocomplete" text field which you can type plan keys into, then click "add", and a list of existing dependencies with an 'X' next to each one to remove it.

Anywhere else in the product this "checkbox for every plan" anti-pattern happens should also be re-examined.  Bulk actions, maybe?
fields.summary: Checkbox tree in dependency management screen does not scale
Bamboo IM Notification Incorrectly Reports NUnit Test Count
Plan with Mercurial repository should have Mercurial capability as Requirement

fields.description:
On all our Clover enabled projects we have the problem, that in the end of the build the collection of the Clover coverage over time fails. The Clover report for each build itself is build correctly and can be accessed via Bamboo.

Our build logs always show the following log lines:

{quote}
simple	09-Jun-2010 11:03:03	Running post build plugin 'Clover Results Collector'
error	09-Jun-2010 11:03:03	Failed to execute plugin 'Clover Results Collector' with error: null
{quote}

And in the end the "Code Coverage Summary" page always shows a zero line for the "Coverage History" and even no line at all for the "Lines of Code History".

(A customer/license number as well as more details to the bug reported can be provided on demand!)
fields.summary: Collection of Clover coverage over time fails for several projects over several runs

fields.description:
When creating/copying a plan, there are implicit build requirements derived from the selected builder. These requirements can not be managed by the user, but are added and deleted on their behalf by Bamboo when selecting a builder.

In 2.6 build 1901 - 27 May 10, when one changed the builder for a plan; the old builder requirement is not removed from the plan:

!Build Requirements.png!

This causes the build to no be able to schedule on desired agents, leaving it in the build queue.

Once saved, the requirements can not be removed; cloning the build plan doesn't work around this issue.

This will only affect plans that change builders.
fields.summary: Implicit 'Build Requirements' from 'Builders' are not removed when changing 'Builders', causes builds to not execute

fields.description: We're running into an [issue in the UPM that prevents us from uploading plugin jars|https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/UPM-489].  I spent some time tracking down the issue and it is caused by the webwork-cleanup filter being run before the REST plugin has a chance to handle the request.  The webwork-cleanup filter is reading and parsing the request entity, making it unavailable to read and parse it in the REST plugin.  The only way I can think to fix this is to only apply the webwork-cleanup filter to paths that have the sitemesh filter applied.
fields.summary: Unable to upload files in plugins using the REST module

fields.description:
When attempting to create my first build plan from a fresh compile of Bamboo 2.6 and 2.6.1, I was met with a stacktrace describing a @NotNull violation when I submitted the form asking for the project and build names/keys -- with a blank description. It did not continue the plan creation.

It pointed to line 40 of com.atlassian.bamboo.project.DefaultProjectManager under the "createProject(@NotNull String key, @NotNull String name)" method. This method dispatches to the 3-parameter "createProject(@NotNull String key, @NotNull String name, @NotNull String description)" -- however it sends null as the value for description.

I changed the method to send in "" instead of null and that issue went away.
fields.summary: @NotNull annotation being triggered from incorrect call

fields.description:
the elastic agent home is located in the small (10G) root partition of the el instance.
the rest of the disk space is available on /mnt which is not used at all!!!

bamboo-agent-home should be linked to use /mnt/bamboo/bamboo-agent-home for bamboo data
/home/bamboo _could_ be linked to  /mnt/bamboo/. for agent logs etc. but this is not urgent,

This issue occurs if no ebs volumes are used.
fields.summary: Elastic bamboo agent (bamboo-agent-home) uses small 10G root partition of elastic instance.

fields.description:
From [ADM-7943|https://extranet.atlassian.com/jira/browse/ADM-7943]: Studio deployments need the ability to use individual user credentials, specified per build plan, when running Maven (particularly in the deploy phase).

I don't know how the credentials would be provided to the builder -- whether to give it a {{settings.xml}} (and {{settings-security.xml}} for password encryption), or just to have a few textfields for username/password...  The implementation doesn't matter all that much, as long as Bamboo users can't get access to each other's creds.
fields.summary: allow maven builder to use credentials in deploy phase

fields.description:
The Grails documentation (and probably Maven and Ant pages in this section) should be improved to clarify the following points made in a customer comment:

* Incorrect: "Please specify file path relative to your plan's root directory (e.g /home/bamboouser/bamboo-home/xml-data/build-dir/MY_PLAN/). Do not specify an absolute path."
(Requires verification - especially for other builders)

* NCover output will be produced: not relevant
(This is true. However, Bamboo's builder configuration screen architecture is such that both the NCover and Clover configuration options appear on all builder configuration screens. Hence, the builder configuration help pages have been updated to indicate which of these code coverage tools _should not be configured_ on the builders to which they don't apply.)
fields.summary: Improve the Specifying a Plan's Builder docs.
